reviewText:
Early Access Review

So I gotta be completely honest here...
This game is freaking beautiful. The animation quality, texturing, modeling, and even the music are all fantastic!
Even the menu for the levels is addictive in a way... I'm actually HOPING they get around to finishing this because the framework of it is really astonishing.
My only complaint is the lack of a tutorial; it kind of sets you out in the middle of the first level with the VERY basic blocks and such and doesn't tell you about certain mechanics.
For instance: You can add steering devices for wheels. STEERING DEVICES FOR WHEELS. I'VE LITERALLY NEVER SEEN ANY OTHER GAME DO THIS BEFORE.
Truthfully, I feel this is going to be one of those great games once (or if... though I hope not if!) the devs finish it.
Really I think I'm going to play more, because this game is something special! :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only played the first 4 or 5 levels, but I would say the game is worth the $7 for early access already.

My favorite part about Kerbal Space Program was unexpected and hilarious explosions, and my favorite part of playing with LEGO was thinking up weird death machines. Besiege has begun to combine those interests, and I'm excited to see where development takes it.

Hopefully there will be many more blocks, weapons, etc to build with. Right now we only have the basics.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is a whole lot of fun with a bunch of creative levels and spawns a whole bunch of creativity inside of you. Besiege also taught me a lot about myself, such as

-Engineering is probably not a viable career choice for me
-Everything that can go wrong, will go wrong
-Things you didn't know that could go wrong, will definitely go wrong
-The things that go wrong, will work out better and beat the level for you
-If you have no idea what you're doing, it's all about luck and how your machine explodes
-I like to find complicated solutions to simple problems because instead of playing all these hard levels that I saw all the videos on where people made 360 noscope machines and mobile Nazi death camps, I ended up playing on the easy levels, like where you just have to kill sheep, and seeing what complicated ways I could recreate Hiroshima on these poor animals.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is the BEST game I've EVER played with my two boys, aged 7 and 9. A+++++ 11/10, best ever. Together we've learned about physics, gravity, centre of mass, flight, ballast, geometery, engineering, problem solving, and other great topics. As a bonus is it probably the first game my wife has shown any interest in too! It's also sparked more interest in the kids toward real-life building, and they've dusted off their lego and are often inspired to build in real life after playing.
In the course of 'beating' the first island we built a number of tanks with progressively better steering and durabily, a couple flying machines including a kamakazee model, a crane, a couple cars, and a number of mostly useless but fun prototypes." Awsome.
I've found many games like this have been too complicated or been burdened by a cumbersome UI. This game perfectly strikes the balance between simplicity and complexity. The game mechanics are deep enough to stay very interesting for a long time
date: and simple enough that we've never been frustrated. I really hope the devs stick to this winning formula they have here and just work on content

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really nice game!
For the price would recommend to anyone, who can sit for few hours and give it a try.

Good+ SteamPlay (Win/Mac/Linux) support
+ It's cheap
+ No limits (expect size, which can be disabled) on what you can build
+ All part available from mission one
+ Little instructions given (just some basic stuff), and you have to use your head to figure out your own approach for each level/stage
+ Playable even with low FPS (quite useful if you have ♥♥♥♥♥♥ PC)
+ Nice visual style
+ Relaxing sandbox experience (at least for me)
+ Active Developer

Bad- No multiplayer (dev's plans are not clear on this point yet :( )
- No steam related features yet (achievements, cards, ....)
- Controls can be clunky at times

Bottom line: best early access game of 2015 (if you are not fixed on multiplayer games)


UPDATE: Feb 23 2015: V0.04: We have Mac/Linux support on Steam now (plus a lot of other changes)
UPDATE: Jul 16 2015: V0.10: Steam Workshop support
UPDATE: Oct 24 2015: V0.20: Unity 5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege.


Man, this game. I watched a stream of it and i instantly bought it.
For the first hour, i thought i was playing the game wrong. Because the game encourages creativity with your machines.
Yet all i built was a block with wheels and studded with cannons.
Is that at all original? Nope.
Did it even work? Kinda.
Was it enough for the objectives? Sometimes.
Did it get wrecked? Yeap.
Did it look totally awesome? Hell yeah!

So far, when you start the game, you are greeted by the main menu which is basically the title of the game, an options menu and a moveable 3d model of the earth (or rather, besiege's version of the earth). Much of the parts of the globe are clickable and they correspond to a level or area in the game. When you click one, it takes you to a table top figurine looking 3d model that again you click in order to choose a level to play in. For now, ipsilon is the only playable area. There are more areas to come soon in future updates.

It was a little hard to figure out how to make working siege machines but when you figure it out, those knights had better watch their backs. Aaaaaand maybe the sheep too. Yes. The sheep. They litter the fields of ipsilon and just graze there like they expect you to just leave them behind. Diabolical little critters, those sheep.
Getting their blood and guts all over my nice siege machine, clogging and gumming up the works with their entrails.
Clever little sheep. Clever indeed.

I really like the charm of the game itself, as it reminded me a lot of crush the castle on iOS only much more expanded and you aren't limited to trebuchets. I hope the devs add more parts, more ammunition types besides the flaming ball and the bomb ball, more weapons and more customization options as well as more enemies cause crushing a ton of em under my siege machine is just plain fun.
The game looks absolutely beautiful as it gives off that kind of tabletop looking vibe and the fact that your siege machine can and will take damage and you see the damage actually happening. Your siege machines have to be structurally sound otherwise your machine could break, burn or explode before you even get the chance to move the machine, kill anything, or blow up stuff.

I just can't get over the tabletop feel of it. It is just so damn cool looking to me.

I recommend it to anyone that likes the medieval era kind of war, anyone who likes simulations and anyone who enjoys building games. Support the devs!

9 Dead sheep out of 10.
Would be a 10 when they add in new stuff for sure.
I hope they add goats in too.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege is a physics based building game where you create all kinds of crazy medieval siege engines to complete objectives ranging from delivering wood to slaughtering sheep. You want a flying block of flamethrowers? Go for it. You want a giant trebuchet? Go for it. You want to make a p*nis? You naughty little so and so, go for it anyway.

+Nice graphics and simplistic level design suit the game well
+The possibilites of what you can make are endless
+The sandbox mode provides a great way of creating and testing different ideas
+Cheap and great value for money
+Physics are pretty realistic
+Variety of different mission objectives as previously mentioned
+A lot of parts to choose from ranging from simple to use blocks to more complex components
+The game has a very basic tutorial which forces you to learn more complex things for yourself encouraging trial and error therefore increasing play-time
+Doesn't require high performance to be playable as long as you use the timescale settings

-There are only fifteen missions at the moment and I can't find any timescale for them implementing all of the missions which are currently unavailable in the game
-No Steamworks features
-The turning mechanic doesn't feel right and is sometimes quite clunky

Verdict:
8

A great physics based builder that's worth the small asking price despite the current lack of content.

El K.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Perfect For Those Of Mischievous And Inventive Determination
+ Excellent gore and fire effects
+ Explosions are both well-rendered and immensely satisfying
+ Extremely polished and optimized
+ Ability to control speed-of-time is both cinematically pleasing and functional; makes it easy to see where contraptions are failing and removes a lot of frusraton from the creative process
+ Open-ended nature of the design-process makes the game furiously addictive
+ Game allows instant transfer between the design square and field testing; no loading screens, no waiting
+ Sharp, fully fleshed-out visuals
+ Minimal background environment, which makes this title feel like a true sandbox game
+ UI and controls are simple, minimalist, and intuitive
+ Crisp and seemingly accurate physics engine

- Game can slow considerably when implementing creations that utilize a large number of blocks
- As of yet, there are cripplingly few available challenges/levels (there is, however, the promise of much content to be released in future updates)

If you enjoyed this review, please follow my curator page. Also, feel free to join my group, LockeProposal's Big Day Out for discussion and announcements. Thanks for reading!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege? Where do I begin?

Well, what is it?
It's like Call of Duty, except less shooting and more quality. They give you the tools and the objectives, you make the epic machinery. Essentially, it's a medieval construction simulation, with some exploding sheep.

How's the gameplay?
I play on a really crappy laptop. Pretty sure it was handed down by my grandfather when he was a child. Anyways, this game still runs smoothly on it. I mean, when I add 124 cannons to my invention it does lag up a little, but c'mon. Who needs 124 cannons, really?
The controls are very easy to learn. As long as you know how to read, you shouldn't have trouble. It falls into the category of easy to learn, but extremely difficult to master. There are literally unlimited possiblities. You just need to have the skills and the knowledge to bring out the true potential this game has.

How're the graphics?
Ugh. They're gorgeous.
You think that literally popping enemies open, watching their guts and blood splatter all over the map as you shred their bodies to pieces with your deadly innovation, wouldn't be beautiful? Well you're wrong.
Every animation, every explosion, every texture, is spot on. Definitely one of my favorite styles of graphics too: clean, organized, easy to navigate, and elegant. You see, I like to be elegant while hacking flocks of birds to pieces and sending pieces of rock from castles and monuments flying into the air.
It makes me feel better about myself.

Is the game buggy? And no, we're not asking you to compare it to an insect.
It does have a few glitches and faults.
But really, don't we all? *whoa man that's deep*
Sometimes, I'll be driving along in my flame-throwing-saw-wielding-semi-flying-ten-wheeled-construction-of-destruction, and the wheels will just decide they can't even anymore, and they flip up in the air and my innocent little vehicle getting torn to pieces. By the air.
That does happen. Sometimes.
But the bugs certainly don't make it unplayable by any stretch. If anything, they're just funny. I'm usually too busy laughing my tonsils out to actually get annoyed at the glitches.

Is it worth the price?
YES. If a game costs less than the price of a sandwich at Burger King, you really can't go wrong. And Besiege does. Enough said.

Does it have any replay value?
Absolutely! Every level leaves you with the feeling of: 'Did I make the awesomest and most effective invention possible for that objective?' ... 'Could I have done it faster?' ... 'Could I have done it without blowing up my entire invention?'
And, generally speaking, that drives you to try again, even if you've already beaten the level.

So, all in all, is Besiege a good game?
Good? GOOD?!?!  IS IT GOOD?!?!
Lol yes.
It's amazing.
It's better than the meal at Burger King that costs the same amount of money, it will last you a lot more time... and heck it has less saturated fat too!
And get this: it's not even done.
There are only 2 areas publicly available as of yet. The second isn't even all the way done.
It's in freaking Early Access. And it's this good.
If you don't buy this, and by the time it's done it's an epic game that costs a lot more and has a huge fanbase, don't say I didn't call it out.
Do your dietary health a favor, skip your lunch at Burger King, eat some celery instead, and buy this game.
You won't regret it.

~ caleb4est

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An average day in the life of besiege:
-Build some kind of car chassis.
-Realize that the car chassis is completely unfit for the task at hand
-Pimp the hell out of the car chassis
-Realize it is extremely weak but very heavy due to all the stuff on it
-Put a ton of braces on it
- Watch as your massive unholy creation from the ninth layer of hell utterly decimates the land, and you writhe your hands in satisfaction
-Just before finishing a level you get bombarded by a chicken who scrapes one of the bombs launchers you have on the side of your majestic beast
-The bombs goes off and what doesn't go rocketing into the air burns into a crisp and ends up in a red and black pile of charred nothingness on the flat ground.
-Sit there
-Contemplate life choices
-press the space bar again twice and thoroughly enjoy the process just as much, but the first thing you do is drive right over and kill that damn chicken.

11/10 best game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

tl;dr: Kerbal Space Program of Medieval Warfare.

Like everyone, I've been burned by early access but this game is truly promising. It is already very, very well functioning.

The building is intuitive, sleek, and polished. The physics are good, and the destruction is pretty decent already and I hope it'll only continue to improve. I absolutely love the art direction, and the art that is in the game is very well done. The music/sound is decent. And although it is obviously a work in progress; between the price and the quality thus far I would say this is definitely something worth checking out.

10/10 emphatically recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I saw some creations around the Internet and ended up buying it.
Well...
BAD IDEA, I CAN'T STOP PLAYING THIS THING, IT'S SO AMAZING,I WANT MY LIFE BACK!

Ok now, seriously.

- Game Engine
Be aware, if you build things really freaking big, it will eat everything that your computer have.
GTA V on Ultra? Piece of Cake, 60fps.
Machine with 478 blocks? Can't go past 3fps when I hit play.

- Physics
They DO work, and it's amazing. You build a plane with less weight on the front? You will only make loops. You build a catapult without reinforcement? It will break in half.
The game devs are probably fired employees from Ubisoft, and they stol all the physics before leaving.

- Gameplay
Build things, Duh.Preferably things that brings death to knights and sheeps. Yeah, those are the best things. Big freaking death things that explode half of the map.

- Sound
Meh. Calm and relaxing.
Change this for god's sake, WE'RE EXPLODING THINGS, GIVE ME SYSTEM OF A DOWN OR MEGADETH!

- Graphics
Not important on this game. It's like Minecraft, it's not about the graphics, it's about the creative possibilities.
But they're pretty good.

- Early Access
Still with 20 levels, but the Sandbox Mode is enabled so you can keep creating things. You will take a lot of time to clear those levels by the way (Flying baloons, I'm talking to you guys, you made me waste 40 minutes only on your level).

That's about it. I deffinitely recommend this game. Waiting for the future updates!

Early Access Review

The ambient music is serene and fits the game perfectly, and in general, this game has so much potential. Buy the game, its only 7 bucks! Support the two developers into making this awesome game.

Early Access Review

What you think it is = Create medieval machinery to acomplish multiple tasks throughout the different levels
What it really is = Create the most ridiculous machine to complete the first level.

After playing you'll question how a $6 low budget alpha at version 0.05 can be tons more fun than the newest AAA title to be ♥♥♥♥ out onto the public.

In short, its much like KSP for pshycopaths.

Also; dear devs, please add multiplayer, medieval battlebots are what we all want, Why you might ask? Because my broken barely working hunk of randomly placed wood is better than your broken barely working hunk of randomly placed wood and I need a game mode to prove it.


Summary: Buy this game because it is absolutely amazing for its price with devs that update and add new content very often, its not overly buggy, its tons of fun, and has massive replayability just building the craziest thing you can, and thats all with only 1 world and a unfinshed sandbox zone.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege is a game where the objective is to build creative and/or effective mechanical structures to destroy villages.  As you progress, the villages build up their defenses, so you'll have to build creatively.  Integrate smashing, explosives, cannons, fire, catapults, and ramming into your village destroying death machine!

Pros:
-Pleasing, vibrant visuals
-Easy to learn
-Well done menu that puts all the building components at your ease
-Great game that makes you think
-Good price for such an abundant game

Cons:
-People who aren't puzzle gamers may find the game tedious or boring

Rating: 9/10 for the average gamer, 10/10 for the puzzle gamer.  Either way it's a great title!

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBesiege is a gem hidden among the trash that has recently come to steam, (cough cough grass simulator). A great game with good physics, beautiful graphics, a relatively easy to use building system, and overall fun gameplay. Smash sheep, splatter soldiers, or just build to your hearts content, the endless possiblities that besiege offers are simply astonishing. I am writing this review in early access, however from what I have seen so far into the game, although only being one campaign level, and a bit of a bugged sandbox, I see a game with the potential to turn into one of the best games on steam. If you enjoy a game that gives you the power to smush over affectionate sheep, create elaborate contraptions, and build practically anything, this is the game for you. Once more, a simply superb game and I hope to see it really live to its potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Percival stood up once more, sweat-soaked armor clanking. He looked around the battlefield, saw the mangled bodies of his dying comrades whose screams filled the air and whose blood soaked into the earth. His sword, which his father had given to him when he left the farm to fight in the service of the Queen, lay shattered in the dust.

He looked straight ahead, where he saw the single thing that had shed so much blood: The Machine of A Thousand Blades. It slowly turned and faced Percival, as if it was some foul beast that had caught wind of his scent. Its wheels creaked and groaned as it began to bear down on this sole survivor.

Percival gasped, and picked up a bow from a fallen comrade. He nocked a single arrow towards this horrendous behemoth of war. His only hope was to find some sort of weak spot in the massive wall of iron that protected the monstrosity. Already mounds of blunted arrows lay cast all over the battlefield, fired by archers who had failed at the very thing Percival was attempting to do.

It came now, closer. A bead of sweat fell to the ground from his forehead. He spared a thought for Gwendolyn: about what their life might have been like had he not been drafted.

The machine was in range. He could wait no longer. He breathed in and fired. Would it hit its mark? Could anyone stop this great war machine? Would Percival live to see his farm again?

lol no. He was sliced in half by a circular saw. 10/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A great game, liked the visuals. If you are apprehensive about touched up images being put in screenshot section of game, don't be. It looks exactly like it indicates it would. Also mechanics play out really nice,there's lot of freedom when it comes to construction of machines. Lack of proper tutorial can be the only factor that I consider to be against this game, i.e. it expects you to know the mechanics of how torque of rotors affects the flight pattern and so on. It would be nice if they included this information in game, not as a ready to build model or anything but some material explaining how various parts behave. Even if they don't there's going to be community made guides about this stuff, so not a deal breaker.

Major factor that's in favor is that it plays incredibly well for an alpha. Framerate drops when there's many blocks but it may also be due to my system not being powerful enough, it's on the minimum side of requirements. Camera needs some time to get used to.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Amazing game. Who DOESN'T want to make helicopters or catapults? Who DOESN'T want to spent 30 minutes making a car to ram over sheep? Who DOESN'T want to make a hammer and fling a knight into space? Who DOES like gravity?

house




Con 1 Only three I can think of. It is extremely easy to kill stuff. I mean, if you poke it oh-so slightly with a spike, it dies.

Silly Thing 1 Why would sheep follow something that's been killing other sheep plenty of times..? But I can't complain, because it's in early access- but the price promises you what you expect out of this game.

Con 2 No level editor :(

Con 3 Needs a preformance fix.

Con 4 Nowhere near complete and needs more levels. Fun nonetheless.

Con 5 Multiplayer should be added. Imagine building a giant crane and flinging your enemy into oblivion... :P

Pro 1 The flexibility of the game is amazing. Not really any restriction. Tons of things you can do.

Pro 2 Another thing that adds more content to the game is the fact that you can also download the .bsg files from the internet and put it in the saved machines folder to play other people's creations!

Pro 3 It is incredibly smooth, and if it starts to lag, in the top left corner you can slow down time.

Pro 4 You get to gib sheep

Pro 5 You can spend HOURS and HOURS and still not get bored (of killing sheep, ofc). You make multiple creations- and if you want you can put them up to download, too.

Pro 6 Saving machines

Pro 7 You get to kill sheep

Pro 8 Sandbox mode. To kill more sheep.

Pro 9 4 god powers- Click to ignite, drag, zero gravity and invincibillity. Adds to pro 1 I suppose.

Pro 10 God damn water cannons. Someone needs to make a waterpark- NOW.

Pro 11 Steam workshop to download creations.

There are probably more pros that I have missed, but these are the basic and the ones I could think.
10 out of 10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OK, so it's definitely early access.  The game is not finished, there's a campaign but only about what looks like 1/4 of it is actually built.  So what does that mean?

Do you buy a game like this to play a campaign?  Probably not.  You buy it for the physics sandbox and the fun you can have trying to make the damn things fly without crashing.

So, the campaign as it is, is fun, but over quick.

The great stuff is, there's an almost infinite number of ways to 'win' each mission depending on what you like to build, for example, one mission I think you're supposed to build a flying machine to kill birds, I couldn't figure out how to build one that'd work so I put a bladed windmill on a post and raised that in front of the oncoming birds and chopped them up, job's right.

You'll find this game will challenge your ingenuity, like what do you do when you need an angled piece of wood?

The not so great stuff is, it's short, not always intuitive and has a reasonably steep learning curve.  If you invest into it (plus there are already a lot of youtube tutorials) you'll be rewarded.

If you like to build, buy this game.  End of story.

Oh and Developers - some decent audio please please please....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

PLEASE NOTE: This is a review of Besiege v0.10 (Alpha).

Besiege could perhaps best be described as the cultivated offspring of Crashtastic and Bad Piggies. Worry not, for this is no bad thing. Besiege is an absolute delight to play. You are given a task to complete, and using a finite space and unlimited resources, you are to complete this task with whatever wacky contraction your humble brain can conjure up. It's a fantastic idea for a game, and it is done near flawlessly in Besiege. Its builder, rightfully so, is extremely in-depth too. Not to worry, though, you hardly need to be the captain of the Junior Architect Squad to be good at this game. I have little to no creative spark when it comes to builders, and I'm getting along just fine. The art direction might be my favourite part of this game, as sad as it is. As someone who adores unique art-styles, Besiege does it all. It has a simplistic, colourful vibe to it. The levels are akin to paint on a canvas; a vast white expanse with the goal variables on top. In a nutshell, it looks beautiful. This game is in Alpha, but my God is it polished. Everything is so refined that you can barely tell it's Early Access, even though the physics can get slightly janky. The drawback of the game being in Alpha, of course, is the lack of levels. One world containing fifteen levels and a sandbox mode is all that's present at the time of writing this review. However, these levels are challenging. The goals given to you get progressively more exigent as you slowly climb the stage selection. Which is good. Besiege is a game of trial & error, and you will have most fun when experimenting with different results; this is where the sandbox mode shines. You are given a skate park-esc stage and unlimited space to build... well, whatever you please. It's a lot of fun, but feels very empty. You can't do very much, bar build something. There are no soldiers to kill, nor structures to knock down, which is a shame. To conclude, Besiege is utterly brilliant. It's a game that screams creativity. If you're a fan of builders, you owe it to yourself to give this game a go.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I can't recommend this highly enough.  While you'll likely begin with a simple wooden go-cart covered in spikes/saws/drills/giant spinning blades, each level nudges you into building some new type of monstrosity, and oh, the monstrosities you shall create.  You'll build catapults, you'll build flying machines, you'll build things that look like medieval torture device carnival rides.  Your engineering failures will be massive and catastrophic, and just as much fun as the successes.

The range of weapons and mechanical pieces provide plenty of options without being redundant.  The mechanical bits (hinges, springs, joints, etc.) allow for an incredible amount of freedom in design (Tip: each activated piece can have both its parameters and hotkey reassigned - e.g. to give each of two opposing springs different elasticity and make them pull separately).  Everything functions smoothly, the physics engine is excellent, and the artistic design is (subjectively) very easy on the eyes.  The Early Access aspect appears to be mainly in content, with additional levels being added over time, but also making it an absolute steal for the price.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

DISCLAIMER: Let me just say that I understand this game came out under a week before I made this review. Okay? Okay.

This game is amazing. Compared to other early access games, it is outstanding; the graphics are polished to perfection, the controls are incredibly user friendly, and it is simply a good game all around. That being said, I only have two complaints.

1: There needs to be some other form of tutorial in which the game guides the user through making different types of machines, possibly even giving the player examples. I only got so much from the tips, and couldn't figure out how to build a plane whatsoever. Regardless, I made death machines. My concern is that unexperienced or close-minded players will begin playing, not understand, rage, and leave a bad review. So, yeah. Just a suggestion.

2: There is not much content. Only one island. And a floating cube-sandbox thing.

Here's a pros and cons list for scrubs who can't be bothered to read my paragraph

Pros:
-destroy ♥♥♥♥ with fire and explosions
-amazing graphics
-no bugs (so far)
-very polished
-i think you can build planes
-only 7 bucks
-you can skip a level if you're stuck

Cons:
-a grand total of 16 levels, including sandbox
-needs more n00b-friendly tutorial
-...that's about it.

IN CONCLUSION:
Amazing game while it lasted, would pick up instantly when it gets updated.
9/10, gr8 m8

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Straight up gameplay:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rt_-_3Wj9TA

Besiege is a fun physics based game where you build a mechanism to destroy different objectives.

The building in the game is very smooth and certainly polished as there are little to no bugs, which is suprising as it's early access. There is a wide variety of things to choose from and the ways you can build are very limitless so that creating things can be done with a lot of freedom, you can build huge moveable towers, seige engines, catapults and even flying machines!

When it comes to the execution of your builds everything is physics based, your machines structure is affected by gravity and many other realistic factors, this allows you to apply common knowledge to your build and also makes it challenging and introduces this games aspect of experimentation. It is very enjoyable tweaking things around and making things work and at the same time it is quite hilarious watching some dumb builds fall over and sometimes explode. Destroying objects such as farm animals and players is quite hilarious, watching masses of bodies spinning in the air without limbs. God i'm weird. Destroying buildings is like knocking down a tower of playing blocks, and it's quite enjoyable to watch!

The game is quite small but it is definately worth the price, although the base of the game is small, it seems to be a game I would personally easily spend 50 hours on!

Great physics engine and building game with literally endless possibilities. You'll need to be creative yet practical to destroy, steal, and kill your way through a limited yet somewhat challenging series of levels. It'll take you at least an hour to figure out all the mechanics, as there is no tutorial for each and every part. The graphics are wonderful making every screenshot you take seem like a piece of art. Bugs in this game are more hilarious than game-breaking.

Pros:
- Endless possibilities
- Download other people's creations
- Nice set of levels
- More to come
- Lots of weapons and parts
- Gorgeous graphics
- Nice medieval style
- Flight is possible and even necessary for some levels
- Good price

Cons
- No tutorial
- Somewhat slow updates
- Singleplayer
- Community is not well-developed past youtube

Overall 8.6/10

Brief Review

Besiege requires you to build a machine to overcome a specific goal. Engineering in Besiege is beautifully simple. Like Lego it’s simply snapping together blocks. Besiege missions gradually get harder and harder

Pros and Cons

Pros

Killing Sheep
Killing Little People
Watching Things Pop In Pools Of Blood
Simple Controls
Simple Building Mechanics
Optimized Game
So Many Pros That I Would Be Here For Ever

Cons

None

An Ending

There are few bigger joys in life than building something insanely ambitious only to find that it works. Ok I lied!! The only thing that tops it is smashing apart something equally elaborate and watching it collapse into hundreds of tiny pieces.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a game that I highly recommend. It's one of the few non-broken steam greenlight/early access games.

The engine is beautiful and I'm really impressed by the visuals. It's a really nice toy-box kind of look that gives a kind of serenity to your slaughter. It also runs great and I have had no performance issues whatsoever. I haven't heard how it runs on low-end systems, however. I'd be interested to see it run on potato-like laptop to see if the minimum specs listed are truely accurate.

The building works well and personally I don't believe that there is anything they need to do to improve it. It's intuitive and works well. It's pretty clear what the parts do from the 1-2 word names that the parts have. I'm also assuming that there is going to be more parts added to the game as the alpha progresses.

Overall the gameplay is fun and has replay value. A major concern of mine that the physics engine would be broken or glitchy turned out to not be true. Everything works how you would expect it to and the consistency of the engine makes troubleshooting your designs easy.

My first straight run took about 100 minutes. However, I am going to replay it many times to see just how ridiculous of contraptions I can make to complete the objectives.

With some really minor improvements and expansion to the content already present, as well as levels being added eventually, this is going to be an even better game than it is now. Well worth the $7. 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent game, especially for the current price (7 USD), though once they add more levels, it'd easily be worth double that. Though at the time of writing this review, the game does suffer from some minor problems due to it being early access. The game itself is fun, engaging, and challanging. It's a unique experience at full of replayability.

The objectives are simple enough. Currently you will either be asked to destroy something, move something, or go to something. The levels are also simple and clean, much like the (very attractive, though still simple) graphics. In fact, the entire game is only about 100 megs, which for a full 3d game with this much dynamic content, says a lot about how much the developer(s) care about keeping it efficient. The interface is a little bit more complicated, but only because of the inherint complexity of building things.

And this is where the game really shines, with building things. There are only about 40 parts, at a guess, but with them you can build pretty much anything you set your mind to, so long as you aren't too ridiculous. Catapults and go-carts are only the tip of the iceburg. Build a machine gun! A helicopter! A transformer! The only limit is your imagination and you mechanical prowess. After beating all the currently available levels (about 15, at another guess), I had the urge to go play them again, but differently, and possibly with self-imposed challanges like 'no wheels'.

I doubt that the game will give you hundreds of hours of playtime, but it will deliver nigh-unrivaled entertainment (and potentially, challange!) in a much more compact package than most games these days.

The only real problem I can see someone having is if they are extremely impatient and easily frustrated. A friend of mine who is a little impatient enjoys the game, but if you're the type who mashes buttons and yells at your computer, well, we don't need you, but you're probably on a console anyway.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege is a fun physics based contstruction game, set in the medevil times, where you construct a structor of descruction, of your design, with the objects, tools, and weapons handed to you to make use of, and it's fun!

Looking at the videos, I thought that I wouldn't know how to be good at this game, starting it out and playing for the first half an hour, so I gave up for a little bit and went to look at some community pictures, and after looking at a few of them, I went back in the game, played for another half an hour, and I was destroying everything elegantly, and improving from then on with better and better structures of destructions.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pVyC3bVo4aM

The game is also really polished too, really slick UI and main menu, and just surprising really neat for an alpha, and the only thing they actually need to do, from what I can see, is just add more complex building parts, more control options / custom controls, a better tutorial with better descriptions of parts, and the rest of the games content in terms of the games campaign which will inevitably be added later on.

What I would like to see, since right now in ever level it's a one shot kind of attack where you can't re-arm yourself, is check points in the more later levels where you go to a certain area in a level to save, repair, reconstruct, and replenish ammo, from there you continue the level and finish it.

There isn't really anything else much to say right now other than the game is good looking with nice graphics, simple controls, and that it is a really fun game with a really high replay value. Also, it's a game where it would definitely benefit from having mod support, with community content flowing into it to keep it alive and kicking for a really, really long time. Worth the purchase? Heck way it is.

Shameless link[www.ksalue.com] to original post.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

*THIS GAME IS EARLY ACCESS*
Therefore alot is not available, currently only a makeshift sandbox world and 1 continent with 15 levels that can be replayed over and over.

First off, this game is beautiful. The maps, the displays, UI, physics; just all beautiful.

I had difficulty in the start because all my cannons would fire at once or my contraption would snap from tension and being to rigid and thats when I realized that this is not just some clicking simulation, no sir. You need to account for torque, being too rigid, weight, moveability, wheels snapping, key mapping, or even just being a big rubberband of wood and wires...

Once you have a stable block of wood that doesnt crumble or self destruct you can add some weapons like cannons or flamethrowers or spikes. Now you don't want all your cannons going off at once since its a one shot weapon so you'll have to change some key mapping for those. Oh right, lets not forget; every action there is reaction, so if you have a weapon on a flimsy limb the force can snap it off...

So after meddling with things maybe you want to head to sandbox (if you're not already there) and try building ballistas' or catapults, all capable with the handy dandy wire thingy that lets you quickly expand/contract it like a rubber band. Or there are these things called pistons that expand/contract themselves into smaller/larger blocks. There are so many possibilities right now it's crazy.

Tired of being on the ground? you can make a FREAKING AIRPLANE. No jokes.

Being an early access there are some bad things of course.
a) Trying to change item when building can spawn one at that spot of clicking instead of changing items (not often, mostly sandbox)
b) The amount of levels is pretty slim but other continents are already laid out for future updates
c) Enemies are slim variety; but as with (b) I'm expecting more as it progresses!

Usually these early access games can cost you an arm and a leg but this one is pretty dirt cheap in comparison and is a ton of fun. If you reaaally don't want to scringe on $7ish and you ever see it on sale, you go buy the crap out of it.

I'm expecting great things from this game; hopefully workshop compatibility, more items/enemies, gamemodes. I don't think I can stress this enough though, this is early access so its missing alot yes, there are a few minor problems yes, but is this still a great game currently? yes.

I thoroughly am enjoying this game. 9.5/10

I chose this or a salad for lunch. I chose right.

10/10, would fly into them again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When speaking of an Early Access title on Steam it is important to note that development is not yet done.  Any comments here about bugs and design issues may have been corrected in an update after this Review has been posted.  Please consider the posting date before using this as a gauge on the quality of the title being looked at.

A physics-based sandbox wherein users are encouraged to create their own war machines using a series of simple mechanical devices; Spiderling Studios' Besiege lets users' creativity run wild with how to be the most destructive and does so beautifully.

While Early Access and Kickstarter began as a way for users to help shape the future of games it has quickly degraded into a way for developers to get a quick cash-in that leaves half-baked messes in end-users' laps.  Titles like Double Fine's Spacebase DF-9 and Broken Age are examples of how to take people's money and give them less than what they paid for in return.  Developers like Double Fine abandon games like Spacebase DF-9 only half completed and missing all the promised depth and challenge.  Besiege, by having promised little more than the ability to make your favourite doomsday device and giving a great deal of mechanics that users can use in any way, has already surpassed my expectations wildly.

At this stage in development Besiege has two game modes: Sandbox and Campaign.  Sandbox sets the player in a space filled with many things to destroy and interact with but no explicit goal.  Campaign however sets the player in a much smaller field with the need to build their war machine to fulfill a specific goal.  Players can be tasked with destroying a castle or village, navigating a minefield to reach a specific point, killing an army, or several things at once.

Just as with Garry's Mod or the Kerbal Space Program, Besiege gives players the ability to do whatever they want and rewards them with an entertaining if not always expected result.  The Internet is already filled with screenshots by more creative users that show off flying cities, walking automatons, and dune buggies.  The limits of ones imagination are really the biggest thing in a player's way.

Spinning bladed death platforms like in the BBC's Robot Wars television series are easy to make, sending streams of blood everywhere as soldiers are rend limb from virtual limb.  You can make ornithopters, helicopters, blimps - it is truly a wonder to find yourself creating a machine to drop a series of flamethrowing platforms on people.

Graphically Besiege takes a light, cartoonish feel while at the same time providing pools, spurts, splashes and mists of blood when killing enemies and innocents via the games many weapons.  Fire and explosion effects give a pseudo-realistic spread and additional destruction that can help and hurt the player's plans.

And then there is the physics.  Besiege's physics take my not entirely useless PC and make it grind to a halt at times.  The more complex you build your war machine, the slower the results will play out.  This of course will be improved by the team at Spiderling Studios as the game continues to grow and take shape, but it can be quite annoying now when you make your bomber rise into the air to drop its payload of flaming bombs and time begins to slow.

Developers are presently looking to refine their physics and add more weapons and mechanics in addition to completing upcoming game modes like the heretofore mysterious Moon, which Spiderling Studios have yet to give concrete details on, but may end up with new physics and enemies to play with.  And where the current campaign mode is just a single continent they are working on an additional four campaigns in order to progress to global domination, and it would be great if with these new continents came new art styles and enemy behaviour.  Where the current continent campaign of Ipsilon is strictly European, perhaps Phi will end up Chinese, Persian, or Indian.  And it would be a nice way to spice up the game were the dev team to introduce a map maker and integrate Steam Workshop for sharing of challenges.  There is a world of potential that Spiderling can bring to the game.

Even as a staunch opponent of Pre-ordering and Early Access purchases - by promising little and giving users a great many ways to do it Besiege has won me over.  If you want a quick laugh as you accidentally blow yourself up, or a challenging interactive puzzle game, you will not be disappointed with this Early Access title.  At 7 dollars, this game is a steal for any creative-types out there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't ususally write reviews, but I made an exception for this game.

Besiege is a Sandbox/Puzzle/Build game where the player's objective is to utterly annihilate enemy structures and armies using their own monstrous machine of destruction. The game features realistic physics, fantastic user interfaces and simple control schemes to assist in the player's creativity.

I haven't played much, but I got hooked the moment I started. I also haven't encountered any glitches or bugs, a rare situation among early access games. The game feels and plays fluidly, not to mention, it looks fantastic. Even though I've only played a few hours, I've created several tanks, catapults and explosives within that time span.

10/10 Would recommend. Totally worth the cost.

I can't wait to see what features will be implemented in future releases of the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

+ Great art style
+ Great music and ambience
+ Good mini campaign available at the moment, more coming
+ Lots of different parts, weapons and gear, new added in every update
+ SANDBOX!
+ If you like it, blood! (can be turned off)
+ Your creativity is pretty much the limit
+ Runs well even in not really powerfull PC's (turning all graphic options off)
+ Just 100 MB to download at the moment

Cons:
- If you don't have a really powerfull computer, creating a large machine will result in a big fps drop. All is fine in the build mode, but as soon as the game starts emulating physics, it can get ugly.


This has been one of the greatest games someone ever gifted me, great early access and price/quality relation.
You can play from 20 mins to 5 hours, it doesn't matter, and you will still have fun.

If you know about physics and design, the game might be easy for you, however, if you are like the vast majority of us you will probably create massive moving.... things at first with 30 cannons and flamethrowers attached to it.
It moves! and looks deadly! You will be very proud of it until you fire the cannons and everything turns to shreds.

But practice makes perfect!
After some hours of playing I could create a reloadable trebuchet with two spare bombs, 8 cannons, two flame throwers, two wheel-blades, two saw blades at the back, and it can convert into battering ram through the power of pistons and a detachable metal spike ball and springs....

They are doing minor updates every 2-3 weeks (blocks, bug fixes, minor features) and major updates (world parts, campaign, major changes) every 2-3 months.
If you like creating things and have a good laugh at comical failure, buy this.


No, really.
Buy it.

Buy it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of people including myself have been burned by some early access game, so naturally I was a little sketical about purchasing it. I can't resist the demolition and bridge builder style of flash games, so I really couldn't help but get it. For $7.79 it's hard to say no anyways.

The game on a whole is very slick. The graphics are very smooth and easy on the eyes, minimalistic. but in such a way that looks very proffesional. The pictures on the store page look cinematic, something you wouldn't expect to find in the game, but it's almost the exact same in game, no added filters to glam it up, the game really does look good. You won't find pictures of it, but the in game menus are stunning, really clean and incredibly proffesional looking.

The gameplay is absurdly fun. You can do pretty much whatever you like and beat the level a hundred different ways. In one of the first levels you destory a small building. You can destory it with a few blocks and some wheels. Or you can create a trebuchet with 78 Cannons attached and 37 flame throwers. If that doesn't tickle your fancy you can make an plane loaded with half a dozen massive bombs and drop them over the tiny house, or just fly right into it.

Tonnes of fun, you can easily spend half an hour building just one machine.

Pros:

-Cheap
-Good graphics
-Really fun
-Good for a quick game
-Good for long game
-Can play a level over and over
-Minimal bugs

Cons:
-Not much for levels right now
-Controls can sometimes feel a little weird
-Could use a bit more variety in blocks
-Still has some bugs (expected, usually hilarious)

Overall, for an early access game, 9/10

Compared to most early access, 11/10.

There seems to be a lot of stuff on the way, and a lot of it is also there as Coming soon"
date: so you can get idea of what is to come as well (like playing on the moon)."

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBesiege is like a wonky ♥♥♥ version of Kerbal Space Program set in the dark ages. You will build many many contraptions of varying utility, most of which will immediately fall apart/spazz out/spontaneously combust upon use. There's only a few maps available at this point, and the phsyics are awesome in a laughably inconsistent kind of way. Still, there's plenty of promise here, and even more importantly, a bus-sized catapult amount of fun. It's totally worth the $7 currently asked by the developers, and anyone even remotely interested in building stuff that breaks other stuff should press add to cart" without hesitation. I rate it as trebuchet/catapult - would definitely spontaneously combust again."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely love this game to death, as it is fun, and so creative for a kid like me with a huge imagination.
It does have just a few downsides...

1. The lag.
The lag is a problem due to many entities moving at once. This is not the greatest for low-end computers. I have a computer with 6GB of RAM and a 1GB GPU, and an iMac with 4GB of RAM and a 128MB GPU. They both run the game fine with small items, but builds with around 100+ blocks lag the computer and start decreasing the framerate dramatically. I would recommend a non-attatched entity remover built into the game. Cannonballs are an example for this. With one of the newer updates, we were intoduced to the Infinite Ammo option, allowing you to spam cannons. There are so many cannonballs not removed that it will start lagging the system trying to calculate all of those entities.

2. Controls
Don't get me wrong, but the controls are fine, but in some ways, they are sorta on the eh" side. Placing braces or blocks are an example. The game will make it move to an undesired location
date:
making you have to remove the block. (That's pretty much it for this.)

3. Semi-glitchy Gameplay
The gameplay is amazing
hoursPlayed: the glitches are funny as hell
voteText: but shaking is something most of us with 30+ hours in the game have noticed. I have made creations that are amazing

votesTotal: but it will need to be fixed in the future. It can get really annoying. Another way of glitching in Besiege is some blocks get caught on other blocks. I have only experienced this a few times
votesFunny: and it isn't that big of a deal

column17: this is just a review in the Early Access time. In future updates
column18: everything will more than likely be fixed. This is NOT to turn away people from buying this game
column19: as it is an absolute rollercoaster of creativity at your fingertips. I would HIGHLY recommend this game for anyone with an extremely creative mind
column20: such as myself.\n\n10/10. I will play this game until the end of time."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Think Kerbal Space Program, only you're not making rockets, you're making siege machines. Catapults, trebuchets, battering rams, battle mechs (?), airplanes, helicopters, and other assorted contraptions.

The visual presentation blew me away, it is easily one of the prettiest looking games I have ever seen!

It is still very early in development, so the content may be lacking, but it does have a sandbox mode where you can test your creations as much as you want.

I completed the first island which serves as sort of an introduction/tutorial to the game, and can't wait for some more missions!

The starting price is also more than fair.

If you like tinkering about and creating machinery stuff, this is the game for you!

Recommended/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By Zeus' beard! This game is totally amazing! Build killing machines with a super simple interface and let loose on high resolution buildings and enemies. Awesome!

The absolute best thing about this game is the silky smooth user interface. There is zero complications in building the killing machine of your dreams! And the physics and fire effects are impressive enough to add another layer of strategy.

The game still needs to be fleshed out with more levels. I think it could use a sandbox mode and maybe a level editor, too.

My only gripe is that these are some parts that I still don't know how to use. I don't know if the game will walk me through their use down the line (some levels emphasize certain parts) but a dedicated tutorial would be nice.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Two rules I generally follow - Don't buy early access games, don't judge an early access game (it's not finished!)
For Besiege, I gleefully break these rules. Besiege is glorious. You build siege engines, flying machines, Rube-Goldberg machines, statues that wave, collapse and catch-fire... You solve puzzle by building bizarre machines. You can set sheep on fire, fire spinning blades at ranks of soldiers, drop bombs from airships onto castles below... And it's still got loads more levels and components to come. For the price tag, it's a steal already.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

An amazing physics-based game.

In Besiege, you'll take the role of a medieval war engineer. You will have to build different siege machines responding to the testing situations the game offers.

Its artstyle and simplistic design may make you think it's an easy game. And you're going to be wrong. Because your first creation, that you'll be proud of, will probably crumble after you fire the first cannon.

Improve your engineering skills, conquer the 2 available continents and build the ultimate siege machine!

Being already a very good game, its designers update it to add new levels to challenge even the best siege machine designers out there. In addition, there's a sandbox map to test your creations. So it can only get better.

It's a 10/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wonderful simulator where, by the looks of things, you play the role of a medieval psychopath who somehow managed to become a military engineer under a monarchic ruler that displays questionable decision-making skills. Your noble sponsor grants you access to all the resources you will need to build machines beyond imagination and sanity. No-one of the royal court will object your decision to siege a castle using a helicopter-catapult and neither they will question the viability of placing a flamethrower next to a wooden beam within your own construction – you are the military engineer and as long as enemies keep falling, you shall be rewarded generously. I say generously, but I simply mean that you will not be seeing your head on a pike of your own bewitched machine, which, frankly enough, used to be quite a big thing for anyone who practiced science in the medieval times.

The game is relatively short at the moment, in fact it is extremely short, but there are promises to expand it significantly. Overall, it is still a nice and a simple game to enjoy in the evening at a price of your fancy Starbucks coffee drink. However, I do need to confess that I consume Starbucks coffee drinks on semi-regular basis, but no-one can judge me as for I am… THE (pronounce “e” as “i” in the word “this”) military engineer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This was the most fun and well made Alpha build of a game I ever played!
At first you may go for simple machines to go through the levels and you'll finish the game quite fast... But it's not the ammount of levels that matter in this game! It's the ammount of different machines and creation you can construct to pass those levels!
You won't get bored of playing the levels over and over again because they'll never be the same! Today you may build a catapult, tomorrow a hammer, the next day a freaking helicopter!!

All I have to say is, for this cheap, this game has more content and stuff to do than many other games out there that cost twice as much or more...

Now, I'm no game critic nor am I quite the game connoisseur, but if someone asked me I'd rate the game as follows:
Gameplay: 8/10 - because if you don't put some effort and thinking into it, chance is, it'll be a simple and possibly clunky machine.

Desgin: 9/10 - Actually I'm not giving a 10/10 because my 10 goes for reallistic graphics, but this is a different realm, and the style is amazing and I wouldn't change it a bit!

Level design: 8/10 - They're simple and straight forward. That's the best and the worst of it. I'd like to see some more intricate levels and I'd love to see community made maps (if that hasn't been implemented yet)

Community creations: 10/10 - I love games where the community can share their work and this game allows it by letting people use others machines blueprint files, and it's as easy as copy pasta :P
And believe me, I've seen some amazing creations. They're just incredible!

Last, but definetly not least...

Fun: 8/10 - You can replay this game over and over again and you'll want to go back to it as soon as you close it!
But why just 8?"

Final score - 8/10 for all the above reasons.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great place to sink your creativity in.

The game is, so far, quite easy to complete. That's not the point, though - clearing levels is just a way of unlocking maps on which you can build.

The real reason for playing this is for the intuitive and addictive creation experience. Imagine having an infinite supply of Legos (or as many as your computer can render) and then adding a splash of physics and great art direction that moves everything from what could have been a sterile/bland setting, to a cartoonish and fun playing field. Even when you fail miserably at something, it's still fun to see it crumble and burn/explode (not necessarily in that order).

Recommend it for people that loved their Legos.
voteText: 7 of 7 people (100%) found this review helpful 3 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of those rare games where trial and error is more entertaining than actually passing the mission. The game's only constraints are the current number of block types available and the bounding lines for your creation (which can be shut off in sandbox mode.)

My only complaints for the game (still in alpha atm, of course):

Number one is the camera. It's horrible right now, forcing you to look at very odd angles to see something. A problem that is compounded when testing your contraption in combat. You can't zoom in on a certain point, but rather at the center point of the creation box.

The game can quickly bog down your computer on some levels, the framerate plummeting as an entire group of soldiers goes from alive to blood smear without the in-between animation.

The music, minor but still an issue, quickly gets annoying. It sounds like No Particular Place To Go" and I can only take so much Chuck Berry when the same two lines of a song play through my head as I'm trying to kill. I'm sure it's just me and shows I'm only nitpicking as the mute button works just as well on here as it does on ads.

One thing that is worth noting is the lack of a tutorial. This game is fine with starting you out with nothing as the first few missions are only testing beds and have no risk but challenge you to add onto your initial creations. But a tutorial for basic designs (or starting with a few simple designs) would have been helpful. Learning what use a few blocks have or how to make the most of other blocks would be useful as well. Otherwise
date: there's always youtube and the trial and error process.\n\nThe graphics are wildly entertaining and makes me feel like I'm tearing through the glass villages my mother used to set up during the winter. Which actually makes it far more satisfying. Your creation has no limits at all to what you want to put on it
recommended: BUT keep in mind that weight is a huge part of this physics engine and your "liberator" can break apart under its own weight.\n\nThe only thing I'd say is that in its current state the price is on par for a large game. Meaning you are spending more on this than you would for a phone app of the same content. Worth the price but will only be giving you new stuff for about two hours upon which time you will need to replay missions with impractical contraptions. However
hoursPlayed: the main menu shows that LOTS of stuff is still planned for the future."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great Game. Very simple controls and building, but you can do a lot with what it gives you. I was really impressed with the different interactions between the parts, There are a ton of different ways to approach each mission, and comparing and contrasting methods with my friends is the best part. I can't wait for more levels. Some things i would like to see for the future with this game:

1. A Map Editor.  This would increase the life of the game indefinitely, because you could download and share maps. A good Map Editor would be amazing.

2. Multiplayer. Either in sandbox mode or the above mentioned map editor if that's possilbe. Being able to load in multiple different machines would add a lot to the game. You could have races,  dog fights, tank fights, or anything. That would be the difference between a game that you can put 40 or 50 hours into and a game that you can put 300 hours into.

That being said, even without those features this game is great and I highly recommend it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege.
Besiege everyone and everything in this fantastic little construction sim.
Wreck havoc with an arsenal of never-ending doomsday-devices... or blow your petty little wood-constructions up in another inferno of frustration and flames, as you fail to just get it right time and time again.

What, you though building a trebuchet is a walk in the park?

For an Early Access and considering it's current price,  Besiege"  leaves a pretty polished impression. I did not encounter any bugs so far
date: at least none i noticed. The seemingly purposive and minimal graphics may not be to everyones liking
recommended: but i enjoy the overall sandbox-feel and the downright cute style.\nIt's like playing legos
hoursPlayed:
just with explosions.

There are not too many stages currently but the ones present so far prove to be quiet diversified and i'm looking forward to more creative challenges.

I'd recommend this little gem to anyone who likes building
voteText: creative challenges and also to those who just like to experiment with crazy gadgets like  flying rotary saw bombs   (very effective once you manage to detonate them more than 3 feet away) ."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have seen a lot of Besiege screenshots, clips and gifs of brutal warmachines on the internet lately. I became pretty curious about this game, and thought: Why not?
I am not disappointed about my purchase. Time flies by when building these machines. And the interesting thing is: you don't have to build a war machine in every level. Sometimes you just need to build a vehicle to complete a level. You can be creative in the things you build and how you want to complete the levels.
And it is not always easy to build a good working machine. Sometimes you find out that the construction is not strong enough and the machine falls apart. Or maybe you find out that you had to use other weapons to destroy something.

If you just want to build machines without any limits and see how they work, you can play it in the sandbox mode, which gives you a lot more freedom.

The graphics are simple and cartoony, but they still look nice and pretty.  The UI is simple but also very clear. There are also a few tutorials about the very basics, but later you have to find out how you build something.

Although this is an Early Access game, I think it is a good one so far. It is not finished yet, they add more building parts in updates.  And there is yet one zone with 16 levels to complete, but here are more to come in the future. And I am looking forward to the new levels to complete.

My rating for this game: 8/10.

for a serious review scroll down a little








Honestly this is one of the best and most creative games i've ever played, the mechanics were used by popular games like Autocraft or Crashtastic but Besiege perfected it. they gave it an unbelievably perfect feel, with good graphics. And despite the fact this is an extremely early alpha game (only 0.04 as of the publishing of this review) it has next to no bugs and has more gameplay than you'd expect from a 60 dollar game for only 7 dollars US. It really brings out the creativity in people. It seems so simple from what you've seen until you play it when you realize al the potential. If you're thinking about buying this and you're looking in the reviews to see if it's worth it then it's a yes from me. i'd give it an honest rating of 9/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game was a blast to play. I absolutely love the look of it, the art direction is stellar and the developer really nailed a unique look that blends perfectly with the style of the game.

The gameplay consists of you utilizing a variety of pieces, parts and equipment to make unique and interesting machines and use those machines to complete objectives.

There is only 15 levels currently with the early access version, but they get the gameplay ideas across quite well. There is also some kind of sandbox mode, which I have yet to dip into but I imagine its just straight up building crazy ♥♥♥ devices with less restrictions.

I build a lot of dumb things, and solved the puzzles in odd ways. I then looked up other peoples solutions to the puzzles and was pleasantly surprised to see how many other strange ways there are, it's not just me, everyone is bizarre :)

I highly recommend this at its current price, with more content I could even recommend it at higher price points.

Feel free to check out some of my playthroughs of the games current levels to get a better idea of gameplay if you need it.

http://youtu.be/AziV9tlIP1c

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What is better than inventing medieval war machines? I don’t know, tell me!
Anyway, that’s what Besiege is about: building things, destroying stuff, and, if you’re a creative mind, having a good time. The game offers a broad range of materials, weapons, joints and mechanical structures as well as various unique and challenging levels, and even if all of the zones that exist by now have been conquered, players are able to find new ways of completing their objectives and construct new machines again and again.

I think that anyone can have fun with this small, but fascinating game about medieval besieging, and I’m sure that it will become even more thrilling after its full release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's the Kerbal Space Program but with siege weapons. I'll try to make this to the point and cover the things that matter to someone considering buying.

Simply put, you're given a square space and an unlimited supply of different modular parts to build a vehicle capable of accomplishing a given task depending on which island/mission you're on.

Gameplay overall is solid as could be for an early access game. It generally bodes well when an early access alpha's architecture is as well put together as this one is. 9/10.

The building system is good, I'd say 8.5/10.

Number of blocks and parts is also very good for the tasks they give you. Easily 9/10 for parts.

Mission variety as of this date 5/25/2015 is not great. I beat this game in a single sitdown of an hour and a half before the update, and another hour and a half for the new missions. Luckily since this game is still early access we can at least hope for greater mission variety in some future updates. But as of right now, I'm going to say 4/10.

Sound/Music quality is inconsequential at this point as there is no music and what sound effects are in the game are more atmospheric than anything else. Sure, cannons make a shooting noise or bombs blow up, but there really is no reason to try and check this aspect at this early a stage of this game's development. X/10.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For a game this early in development - the developers are tentatively throwing out a 1.5-2 year period before full release, as mentioned in the EA description section above - Besieged is already showing a ludicrous amount of polish. Graphics and artstyle are shiny, efficient, and stylistically attractive, and there's a solid framework already in place. Meanwhile, the crux of the game's concept, the physics, are wonderfully and hilariously responsive.
10/10 would fail to make a functioning airborne siege engine again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Are you interested in mass hysteria?
Perhaps not.
Well, what about crazy contraptions and the ability to blow anything up?
Okay, whatever.
This might be able to sell you: the ability to blow up said contraptions again and again and again as it never gets old?
Though so.

This game combines three of my favorite gameplay elements: building, explosions, and gore. Now, this game is also part strategy, as well as one that requires patience as, if you're like me, you might need to take 1 to 1000 tries on a level. They did an amazing job with the game, and even though it's got one zone with 11(?) levels, it's still incredibly fun as well as incredibly addicting.

10/10 would explode again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is basically what would happen if Minecraft and Angry Birds met at a bar, had a few too many drinks, then went home with Garry's Mod for a threesome.

There are only 15 levels right now, but the game's been out for a week and a half. Playing through all of them will take you 2-4 hours, depending on how much you goof off. The game feels EXTREMELY well-polished for an Early Access game - I haven't been able to find any bugs at all. Even after completing all the levels, the game is stupidly fun just for seeing what you can build. The graphics, although simple, are beautiful - especially the fire, explosions, and blood splatter.

Basically, if you enjoy building a meat grinder on wheels and running it through hordes of enemy troops while shooting flames everywhere, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I don't like to do reviews for games, but Besiege is an exception; the sheer quality of this game for its stage of development is well worth the £5. The game is updated regularly, which supports the hypothesis that this game will reach full release which often dissuades people with early access games. It does have its bugs and occasionally clunky UI but it is a beautiful sandbox game with real potential. Besiege sparks the imagination to conjure weird, bizarre and wonderful creations that somehow manage to kill all of those suicidal sheep. Even if you do not consider yourself to be a 'creative' person, you will have fun for hours. If you put the time in, it can be hugely rewarding even in this limited state with only 15 levels and a sandbox mode.

TL;DR

Get the game, put the time in, have fun.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSkeptical by the Early Access" title
date: I thought this was going to be a game of broken promises. However
recommended: I decided to give it a shot just because I am a sucker for physics
voteText:
and medieval genres. Besiege is on the path to be one of the best simulators on Steam.

The goal is simple; complete the objective by any means you wish. The tools are quite versatile and allow you to go as far out as you want with your creations. Another dynamic aspect to the game is the physics engine. You could build the most awesome machine but every moment of force is calculated. Even just pulling too hard on your catapult and the whole thing might shatter into wooden bits. Watching shrapnel fly around and bodies ran from the sky will billows of smoke and fire is just purely satisfying.

As of this review (2/10/2015)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While lacking in content, Besiege is endlessly entertaining, in a 'I'm ruining your ♥♥♥♥ lol' way.

Ignoring the lack of content, what's here is already very well polished and plays very well. There's 1 and bit islands to conquer, plus a sandbox mode for all your demolition needs. I haven't encountered any bugs (yet), so I think most updates will be content over bugfixes.

While Besiege relies on player discovery for making things, I think a tutorial or some hints wouldn't go amiss, for concepts such as flight.

But like I said, it's Early Access, so there's still work to be done. But what's here is already very well put together and is perfectly playable. Certainly worth the money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Blam!!, i watch in dismay as another one of my designs crubles before me, another innovative idea gone. Then i think, what could i have done differently, in a spark of creative genuis i set off again to redesign my ultimate machine, the one to rule them all
-The creative work of the besiege toaster gun

This is what it is like playing besiege, you get as much out of it as you put in, and failing is half the fun. The beautiful physics engine paired up with brilliant cartoonish aesthetics will certainly charm you. it can sometimes be frustrating to maticulously go about every design aspect of your masterpiece you are gaurenteed to find help where you most need it. Just a few weeks out of early access a thriving community of youtubers, sculpters and demolition junkies are pouring hours of work into this game, it has so much to offer even with only 12 default levels. As an early access it stands tall amongst others for its surprising fluidity and lack of bugs and glitches.

I dont think i have ever been more satisfied with a 5 pound purchase than i have with besiege, may it live long and prosperous
voteText: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful 4 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Early Access Review

~BESEIGE IMPRESSOINS/REWIEW~

-The Good-
Fun game to mess around with. Has lots of potential overall. Makes building simple for new players, while allowing more advanced minds to create very complex and amazing things. Workshop support is great. The campaign, while short at the moment, provides challanges that go from very easy to moderatley challenging. Very good dev that focus on bringing us new content & bug fixes. Very fun game overall.

-The Bad-
Game can be a bit laggy at times. though this is for the most part only when playing with large explosions/complex machines. Some campaign mission are a little tedious. A few bugs here and there, though this is early access, so was to be expected. Camera can be a little hard to control at times.

-The Ugly-
Graphics/Imagery fit together very well with the medievel theme that beseige sets. Not a huge fan of all the textures but most of them look really good.

-Overall-
I give Beseige a 8.5/10
Would explode the ♥♥♥♥ out of a bunch of sheep again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Blam!!, i watch in dismay as another one of my designs crubles before me, another innovative idea gone. Then i think, what could i have done differently, in a spark of creative genuis i set off again to redesign my ultimate machine, the one to rule them all
-The creative work of the besiege toaster gun

This is what it is like playing besiege, you get as much out of it as you put in, and failing is half the fun. The beautiful physics engine paired up with brilliant cartoonish aesthetics will certainly charm you. it can sometimes be frustrating to maticulously go about every design aspect of your masterpiece you are gaurenteed to find help where you most need it. Just a few weeks out of early access a thriving community of youtubers, sculpters and demolition junkies are pouring hours of work into this game, it has so much to offer even with only 12 default levels. As an early access it stands tall amongst others for its surprising fluidity and lack of bugs and glitches.

I dont think i have ever been more satisfied with a 5 pound purchase than i have with besiege, may it live long and prosperous

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Only a few hours into this game and already loving it. It's a great little building game where the objective is (usually) to smash enemy castles and armies to pieces with a siege machine of your own making. The game also mixes up the missions you do, so you may have to make a crane to collect resources and deliver it somewhere or torch a flock of seagulls. This adds a little spice to the flavour of the game.

It reminds me a lot of Garry's mod - but with objectives. That is a huge plus in my book. Add multiplayer to this and it could well be one of the best games of all time. The price tag is also very welcoming for an EA title - too many devs these days are pricing their games over £15 for EA, which is a huge gamble for a game that is not finished.

Besiege is also fairly bug free and plays very well. It looks and feels very polished for an Early Access game.

All-in-all, this is definitely worthy of your time and I look forward to future developments. This is Early Access done right and I wish there was more like this on Steam.

Jimbo Rating: 8/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

~BESEIGE IMPRESSOINS/REWIEW~

-The Good-
Fun game to mess around with. Has lots of potential overall. Makes building simple for new players, while allowing more advanced minds to create very complex and amazing things. Workshop support is great. The campaign, while short at the moment, provides challanges that go from very easy to moderatley challenging. Very good dev that focus on bringing us new content & bug fixes. Very fun game overall.

-The Bad-
Game can be a bit laggy at times. though this is for the most part only when playing with large explosions/complex machines. Some campaign mission are a little tedious. A few bugs here and there, though this is early access, so was to be expected. Camera can be a little hard to control at times.

-The Ugly-
Graphics/Imagery fit together very well with the medievel theme that beseige sets. Not a huge fan of all the textures but most of them look really good.

-Overall-
I give Beseige a 8.5/10
Would explode the ♥♥♥♥ out of a bunch of sheep again.
