reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fantastic game concept, beautiful yet simple graphics, great interface and all for £5.50!
One of the best game purchases of my life. longtime gamer.
I have looked through the rest of the reviews and it looks as tho the people who do no not recommend the game do so on the basis that they don't believe there is a lot of content, the fact is that for your £5.50 you get 2 islands with some 10 or more levels on each and the sandbox enviroment but you create the content and gameplay for yourself by building whatever your imagination will let you.
The devs are constantly updating and introducing new content which is great.

So to summarise - if you are creative and then like to be hugely destructive this is just the game for you. I can't recommend it highly enough. Keep up the good work.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I absolutely love this game, if you have any money to buy a game, this should be the one!

I also have some potential ideas for future items (These are obviously just ideas, and therefore I do not expect you to put these in)
1. An in built video editor: The trailer for Beseige is one of the best that I have seen in a long time, but not everyone can make their videos that good, my first idea is an in built video editor which allows you to record clips and then edit them with music and such. (Basically like Rockstar video editor, but for Beseige)
2. Multiplayer building mode: Get players to build a machine for a set task or fight, and them place them in an arena for the worlds most insane fights
3. Brakes: One thing that annoys me a tad about Beseige is the fact that when you stop moving a wheel it keeps on spinning, an item that could be used to prevent this could be an item such as a Brake, it would work by attaching it to the side of a wheel and pressing a keybind to activate it, when the keybind is pressed the wheel or gear that it is attached to will stop completely.

So just to reiterate these are some personal ideas, and the game is epic!

This game started amazing.
The wonder of creation in their awesome building system made solving the different challenges so much fun.
The difficulty of the levels is what you make of it. If you decide to go and make it easy for yourself, go ahead. If you want to give yourself restrictions and make it a challenge, go ahead.
But it being in early access, there isn't much content and they're a little slow to add new content, so after the initial levels I kind of lost interest. But then I opened the workshop and found a plethora of constructive creations and spent that much more time playing in sandbox.

Awesome game, add more levels, 9/10

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is what Gmod aspires to be. Far more fun, and is sheer catnip for creativity. It's probably the first game that made me use the same thrust pods found on a LEM in order to create a precision XYZ control method for a stable floating platform with detable weapons packages. The fact that I just typed this should be reason enough to fork over some support money now and reward the duo responsible to finish what is probably the tightest most finished Alpha ever.

It's what RUST aspires to be - and can't - because RUST isn't fun. This is fun. This is insanely polished (the rough edges being some lag for massive machines and some levels - but we're talking optimization - not show-stoppers). It also sits on less than half a gig of your HD - and runs fine on my lowly dual-core 2.4ghz Mac Mini.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege is a physics based game where only your creativity and maybe a little bit of your luck can help you.
Besiege may look like a game you will play for a day or two and then you will forget about it forever. But if you ask me i can see lots of potential in the game .

why you will as ? well let me explaine-Because it does something not many games even dare to do in our days , is make a game where you need to think and use your Imagination.
Sadly in our days most of the games are based on simple rules or maybe not even a single rule , leaving you just looking at the screen and clicking.
And besiege is not one of those games. Besiege has no real tutorial as you get into the game. So its your duty to figure out how to play. But don't worry its not just trows you into the water and says swim ****! No its starts slowly with an easy task and slowly moves to bigger and harder challenges.

Right now as its in alpha its not much contant, yes .
but as i said its only alpha so meaning lots of contant will be added in the near future. And already you can see whats the map size is going to be and what the devs are working on and (hell know how many levels every piece of land contains).
Plus for the price tag of 6.99$ you can't really complain , and the replay ability is huge.
And if you're still scared picking this game up just because its in alpha" and its "100% full of bugs and all those things" forget about it. As long as i have played there are no bugs at all
date: yes im pretty sure its not gonna be some bugs here and there. But even if you find some they are so little and unnoticeable at first you would not even care.\nSo if you ask me the game is in alpha just because its really not that much contant
recommended:
but even now its lots of what you can do.

So if you ever had an idea of picking up Besiege go for it 100% i think its a wonderful game and its for sure deserves your attention.
Thank you for reading my review and peace ! <3"

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege can be adequately described as the best and most limitless creativity toy around. It's, as you can probably already tell, a medieval-styled Crazy Machines with unlimited parts and well... medieval objectives.

Why settle with a Trebuchet though if you can take to the skies in a Da-Vinci-like flying machine just to rain down fire on the enemy? Build a giant chariot with sawblades like in the trailer and watch your foes crumble and be gored to perfection, and if there is any true siege work on castles to be done, you can always deliver explosives right to the enemy's doorstep. How? Your way!

Be wary of your amazing contraption taking fire though, those cannons and blades are going to be hard to use when your machine falls apart into ashes. Armour provides proof against hazards like oil pots, arrow fire and gouts of flames, but with the main part of your contraption made of reinforced plywood and medieval acceleration at it's finest/weakest, it's going to slow you down quite a bit.

The Scenatios only restrict you in how big your vehicle/tower/plane/gun platform/glider/paradropper or hybrid can be and if you already completed a level, you can switch off this restriction at any point for unlimited siegecraft.

I also must say that the game is very hardware-friendly and performs well for a freeform physics sandbox. Add to all that the spectacle on which you are probably most likely (I hope so for you) is served at an absolute bargain price and getting updated regularly, I only have one question to ask to you, dear reader:

Why are you NOT playing this game right now?

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I felt compelled to write a review for this game purely because I saw so many other reviews that bemoaned the lack of a tutorial....

The thing that sets this game apart in my mind is that it reminds me of that feeling of....potential and excitement I used to feel when I tipped my bucket of Lego onto the mat and started thinking about what I was going to build. You have a selection of blocks that behave in certain ways, then you have fairly open ended puzzle levels which call on you to construct a slapdash/rickety/barely effective and dangerous looking contraption.

The graphics and UI are nicely stylised and they have really done an amazing job at making the building process intuitive, and in that I mean that if this was implemented badly the building process would go from quick and pleasurable to arduous and unpleasant. Immediate comparisons can be drawn with Kerbal Space Program which I also love, though I would say that this game has more polish and I find myself hitting the 'undo' a lot less with this very well laid out and implemented UI.

While this game is in early access it is not a buggy piece of S*&^T but essentially a release ready game that just has a limited feature set. I already feel that I have got my money's worth out of this and there are still additional levels and content to be added.

This game does what it says on the tin, and it does it well. To return to the negative point mentioned in many other user reviews of a lack of tutorial however.... I really think this is unecessary, the lack of a tutorial is part of what I liked about this game, it is about trial and error....'I wonder what this thing does?' you add it, push space, and see what it does, your contraption ineviteably blows up, press space, make modification, press space, test, repeat, PROFIT.

All of my catapults use steering hinges, when I push left, the catapult arm raises, if my catapult also requires steering, when I'm moving and turn left, the catapult arm raises, often an unwanted result.  BUT IT IS PART OF THE CHARM! Half the puzzle is figuring out how best to implement the pieces at your disposal, a tutorial will just end up giving you preconcieved notions in that area, it is more fun to end up with a whole lot of half-♥♥♥♥♥, barely working deathmachines as opposed to slick and boring, 'correctly' put together deathmachines (less hillarious mishaps and explosions for one thing).

In summation.

Buy it, enjoy figuring out how things work, and then determine exactly HOW many bombs you can launch at one time....

$7 well spent....

reviewText:
Early Access Review

So let's see... Thus far I've built a siege-worthy lawn mower, equipped with a bomb launcher, naturally; a Da Vinci-style aircraft capable of destroying castles from the air; ballistas and siege-engines galore; planes, tanks, and assorted little instruments of doom.

This may still be early alpha, but it already feels polished enough to be a full - if small - game. The only thing I want from it right now are more levels to conquer, and maybe more parts. If all a game leaves you wanting is more, that's probably a good thing.

It won't take long to finish at this stage, but it's a real blast for the time you spend.

The art style is clean, cute and has a board game feel to it. The physics are fun and feel spot on. If you are willing to deal with the possible headaches that come with a early access title, and enjoy games such as space engineers and other forms of building block games, you should get a kick out of this. The current price is around 6.99 and I feel it was money well spent.

This will be updated at release.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

10/10. This game will blow you up and make you LOL like a wee child. The levels are fun. The explosions will make you jovial. The slaughter of white sheep popping under your wheels will make you gush with happiness.

However, the camera may cause you to lose some hair. I found it to be extremely frustrating and hardly ever where I wanted it to be. There are no options in switching controls, or how to navigate the camera, so you're just stuck with whatever settings they give you. While this didn't ruin the game for me, it did make certain aspects more difficult to enjoy; especially when you're driving your craft, trying to blow up that citadel, and then the camera never moves, so you're stuck right-clicking, using the arrow keys, and attempting to press 'Y' at the same time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege is really a one of a kind game and it feels extraordinarily polished for an alpha (even a beta). I played through the entire campaign & messed around in sandbox mode. I’ve spent a total of about six hours in game which equates to about a dollar an hour for its current price; however, when they release more content I’d hope they increase the price as the developer really deserves the money.
Even if development was to completely halt and future progress was not guaranteed it’s still worth buying in its current state.
Anyone that says it doesn’t contain enough content for the price is a fool. It costs about the same as a standard DLC for other games and equates to about the same length of playability before it gets boring.
The only real issues I had was I felt like the driving of the siege engine could have been improved (however it’s still fantastic as it is), and sometimes the camera / object placement could be a little janky.
It’s important to note that if you want to get your money’s worth (which in my opinion is about 6-7 hours) don’t just rush through the levels… take your time and enjoy them, see what crazy contraptions you can build to achieve your goals.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nBesiege is one of the games that does early access right. It doesn't have masses of content, but all of the content that is there is polished very masterfully.  It is a game based around building siege engines of amazingness, doom and destruction. Of course they have to be functional and not break. As of the time of writing this review, you only have the Isle of Ipsilon levels and the Sandbox, but they are plenty to sustain as the creation of machines is addictive and amazingly intricate things can be created. In the levels you are given a simple goal and you need to build a machine to wreck that puny little foolish goal under your timeline breaking wizard building powers! There is a limited area to build in and there is a fairly small ammount of bits to built from at the time of writing, but those parts are so versatile that a person with a good imagination and skill/experience can build many, many different fun and interesting machines. In any level, or the sandbox, you can remove the building limitation and build massive, insane things. All the content is polished, the game is addictive as hell. A complete and full reccomendation from me.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a physics puzzler by which you need to build different siege engines to accomplish each level's objective. For instance, the first level requires you to destroy a small house. The second level requires you to adapt your design to destroy a windmill on a hill.

The current levels as of February 8th are 15 campaign levels and a sanbbox obstacle course.

The parts to build with are varied from basic blocks to pistons to springs and many other weapons like blades, spikes, and even bombd. And the build mode is very intuitive.

The graphics settings can enable and disable SSAO, Shadows, Bloom, and Vignette. In the same settings folder, you can find an option to ignite anything with a click of a button, and disable the build limits.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's a lot of great things to say about this game.  The graphics and models are easy on the eyes, the music is serene, and the physics are pretty darned realistic.  My only complaint is the lack of a tutorial, which is significant considering the learning curve.  I admit that I did partially have fun failing in the creations I made, but I also found myself frustrated at times because I couldn't figure out how certain parts worked together.  I'm hoping to see some sort of in-game video tutorial showing first-time players how most of these parts function as a whole.  For now, I'll be consulting Wikis and YouTube videos.  Considering the price however, I'd say that $6.99 is a great deal for what you're getting here.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ALPHA V0.04

As always I was weary of an Early Acces title, but I had been looking for a game like Banjo Kazooie: Nuts and Bolts (hey, it was good in it's own right) and after reading the Early Acces thingy I was convinced for two reasons: they promised variety in levels aestethics and gameplay and they promised to always deliver a price proportionate to the content. So I bought this in it's earliest form, so I could eventually enjoy all of the content at the cheapest price. And to be honest, I was surprised by how robust this V0.04 alpha already is. The mechanics feel very near completion. My only problem is the lack of actual levels, but for 7 bucks this game is worth your money. And if they deliver upon their promises this game will eventually be worth way more than the 7 bucks you paid for it.

If you're into building vehicles with physics and driving them around, this game's just the best there is. Even at this stage it's a blast, and that's at version 0.04. I can only imagine what this game will be like in a year from now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I really, really like this game! In just a few seconds i made up a suicide bomber car and a wall of cannons and laughed my ♥♥♥ of as i completed the level and my creations toppled down.

All in all it is still in development but very functional, and the few build options (and they are not really few but yet, they need to be expanded) already guarantee hours of fun. Just looking at your own machine fail on you is fun itself.

The user interface is nice and the game , while looking good, is not too hard on the PC and could be run (i think) on any semi-decent PC.

All in all, the game look REALLY promising and , considering the price, should be bought as an investment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Funny, Creative, and very easy to get into.

Besiege is a game where you build contraptions to complete the objective(s) in each stage. Every stage can be completed in a multitude of different ways, as long as you complete the required objective(s). This game is open from start to finish, you dont have to beat every stage to unlock certain parts, cheats, or any feature, You can even disable the box which limits how big your creation can be, and where it spawns (this ofcourse prevents level progression, but all the levels are already unlocked for you). There are quite a few parts, ranging from construction bits, to mechanical moving parts, and weapons. You can build anything from a medieval tank, a catapult, and even a giant walking death robot with the right skill and parts.

You dont need a NASA gaming computer to run this game (however it does help if you build absurdly large creations with tons of moving parts), and for only $6.99 this game is excellent. There are few to no game breaking bugs that I can think of or have encountered, and the game runs very smooth. If you dont know what to buy, and have 7 dollars, pick this game up, its great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is the sandbox I've been looking for that has been done right! While you cannot do everything in the game, you're really only limited by your ingenuity and creativity. Relates closely with lego's in the form of what you can do; not everything, but more than enough to keep you busy.

Every update so far has provided users with yet more tools to tinker around with in Besiege. For $7 this game has already paid itself off in my mind and I'm already more than happy with how the game is in its current state. The sandbox mode alone is worth the small price.

Get this game if you enjoy building intricate contraptions/vehicles or just flat out enjoy messing around with sandboxes.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a physics puzzler by which you need to build different siege engines to accomplish each level's objective. For instance, the first level requires you to destroy a small house. The second level requires you to adapt your design to destroy a windmill on a hill.

The current levels as of February 8th are 15 campaign levels and a sanbbox obstacle course.

The parts to build with are varied from basic blocks to pistons to springs and many other weapons like blades, spikes, and even bombd. And the build mode is very intuitive.

The graphics settings can enable and disable SSAO, Shadows, Bloom, and Vignette. In the same settings folder, you can find an option to ignite anything with a click of a button, and disable the build limits.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

If you're into building machines capable of blowing up an entire castle, then look no further, this is the game for you. It has strong aspects when it comes to physics, which behaved 'rather' realistically. The game so far is worth it for its price, despite it being an early access game. I have to say this is probably one the best...no, no, THE BEST early access game I've ever played, for its price I would get it right now!~
Do remember, THIS IS AN EARLY ACCESS REVIEW!!!

Pros:
-Realistic Physics
-Easy building mechanic (nothing fancy)
-Medival Legos

Cons:
-Messy Camera angles (please do fix this, its a very annoying downside to the game)
-Not yet optimised properly (this occurs when you build a medium-large machine and your FPS drops from 55 to 12 when you try and simulate it).
-Lacks flight options (A lot, in fact)

Overall, this game has a lot of potential especially when those 'cons' are taken care of.
FOR THE DEVS, I would like to see more awesome content in the future and more 'flight' options.

I would give this game an early access score of 85/100

reviewText:
Early Access Review

There's a lot of great things to say about this game.  The graphics and models are easy on the eyes, the music is serene, and the physics are pretty darned realistic.  My only complaint is the lack of a tutorial, which is significant considering the learning curve.  I admit that I did partially have fun failing in the creations I made, but I also found myself frustrated at times because I couldn't figure out how certain parts worked together.  I'm hoping to see some sort of in-game video tutorial showing first-time players how most of these parts function as a whole.  For now, I'll be consulting Wikis and YouTube videos.  Considering the price however, I'd say that $6.99 is a great deal for what you're getting here.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cfStN6pWhgE

reviewText:
Early Access Review

(Review date: 03/23/2015 - This is an Early Access game, the criticism on this Review may change as the game updates).

Besiege is a Sandbox game which you have the power of building whatever you want, with objects such as Wheels, Weapons (Flame Throwers, Cannons, Water Cannons, Large Spikes and much more), and other objects which help with your vehicle/machine/thing to work (such as traction, suspensions and movements). You can pretty much build anything you like with the assets that the game comes with. You can also flip several objects to work in reverse ways (E.g.: Wheel running backwards), and so on. You can save your machines any time you like and how many you like as well.

The game has a Sandbox mode and a Campaign mode. Right now only one Chapter" of levels exist

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ALPHA V0.04

As always I was weary of an Early Acces title, but I had been looking for a game like Banjo Kazooie: Nuts and Bolts (hey, it was good in it's own right) and after reading the Early Acces thingy I was convinced for two reasons: they promised variety in levels aestethics and gameplay and they promised to always deliver a price proportionate to the content. So I bought this in it's earliest form, so I could eventually enjoy all of the content at the cheapest price. And to be honest, I was surprised by how robust this V0.04 alpha already is. The mechanics feel very near completion. My only problem is the lack of actual levels, but for 7 bucks this game is worth your money. And if they deliver upon their promises this game will eventually be worth way more than the 7 bucks you paid for it.

If you're into building vehicles with physics and driving them around, this game's just the best there is. Even at this stage it's a blast, and that's at version 0.04. I can only imagine what this game will be like in a year from now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I... I don't even. Like, really? It's impossible for a game this simple and inexpensive to be incredibly fun.

If you play the Sims and only enjoy the build mode and the opportunity to murder your family members, this game is for you.
If you're a puzzle-lover who also enjoys playing with Lincoln Logs, this game is for you.
If you're a mechanical engineer, this game is for you.
If, as a child or in present day, you ever enjoyed building intricate buildings or vehicles just to demolish them, this game is for you.

If you like to blow stuff up, tear stuff down, catch everything on fire, and stealing things, all while trying to protect and engineer your little device from hell, you should stop reading and go buy this game. Now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A lot of early access games are in bad condition or unplayabe, in such cases, I'll often come back to check them out as they're further along in development.

Besiege is still lacking in full content, but what's there already shows a remarkably high level of polish, and is a lot of fun. I spent several hours just messing around, trying to create all manner of crazy contraptions. The highlights of which include, a functional trebuchet, a full tank with articulated turret, and a working ballista.

You'll likely fail often, and when you do, you're rewarded with hilarious mechanical breakdowns, explosions, and slo-mo fireballs. Instead of getting frustrated, I generally find myself laughing at what just played out on screen.

I just hope they add rockets at some point ;)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really love the possibilities of what you can build, and the variation of things you can use to make stuff. It's one of those games that you spend an hour on, but realize it's been 3 hours, it's just so entertaining. Levels have a lot of variation and are pretty satisfying to complete. The graphics are very appealing and have a nice mixture of cartoon and reaistic looking stuff. The physics is generally pretty top notch, although it's a bit glitchy at times, but what game isn't? It would be nice if the collision on objects could just be touched up a bit, but it's really no big deal, barely effects the majority of gameplay. Looking forward to future updates for more levels and stuff.

OVERALL: I'd give it a 7/10 right now, but it looks like that's going to eventually be a 10 in future updates, considering the most recent one was so good. GOOD JOB GUYS THANKS FOR MAKING THIS IT'S FUN BYE.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The first thing I will say is that the archers just do not give a crap.  I mean, I light them on fire and/or take out half of them, and they just keep shooting arrows, with little to no effect (while they are burning!).  As for building, I have yet to figure out how to fly, but what I have done on the ground has been some of the most amusing time I have spent in a game in a while.  My best creation at the time of writing this has 5 cannons, 2 flame throwers, 10 blades attached to it's weels, and a giant launcher that shoots a flaming boulder.  The one thing this game could use (aside from more levels/level editor/better sandbox/more parts) is Steam Workshop support.  For the price right now, it's well worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A game that is in early devolpment, and isn't about plane crashes, voxel survival, or a zombie plague? Gaben be praised!

Well worth the 7 dollars, not much in the game yet but the possiblites look great. Workshop add-ons, multiplayer contraption figthing, and a fun sandbox buliding game similar to kerbal space program is what I hope see in this game's future.

Also it runs very well for a unfinshed game (unless you place way more blocks and parts than you know you should be). Solid frame rate and great graphics. Looks very polished even though it's still in development. The only bug I ran into was that sometimes you accidently might put 2 parts in one spot if your clicking too fast and not paying attention. That might be my mouse however.

I suggest you pick it up if you have an extra 7 dollars laying around or the game goes on sale. It's pretty fun, and more updates are bound to come. For now, it just has a few fun levels and a sandbox. So don't excpect that much to do until some extra content get's rolled out. But still a pretty solid game. 7/10 for what it has to offer as of now.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Liquifying sheep with a Da Vinci bomberplane 10/10

But seriously, this game is amazing. You can build whatever siege device you can imagine, whether it be catapults, cannons, flamethrowers, towers, rams, rolling butcher stations, or even planes. It brings out your creative destructive side, bringing the most devastation at any price.

The only complaint I have found is with the camera, which can be a bit disagreeable at times, but the reset camera button fixes it for a while.

I don't know why you're still reading this. Go, buy the damn game already!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Let Start off by saying This review is by a german, and thusly Spelling mistakes will occur as i am using english.
good Now Lets get to the fun bit!
Besiege is absoluteley Wünderbar! so lets get to the pros and Cons

Pro's
+Intuitive building system
+The medival setting
+the game has a slow time mechanic which helps when wanting to test Huge Machines.
+the physics are Great i love it
+almost 0 bugs
+it is actually updating instead of being abandones

Con's
-The game does have some bugs that i have found
-it isn't configured to handle Huge machinery's  ATM however dont let that stop you due to the time slowing ability

Bugs
- the spring bug, i have seen this myself and it is not good the springs will go super far out and it can ruin the asthetic however it isnt game breaking
-when going out of game to do something on my comp after 2 times of doing this it wont let me enter the game or do anything which causes sadly for me to have to restart (devs get on this!)


Do i reccoment this game all and all? Yes Absoluteley for the minor problems it has it is way better than the dog ♥♥♥♥ that usually climbs out of greenlight good on theese devs. good on them.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI don't often buy indie games. I decided to splurge. In my country with terrible exhcange rates even 7 bucks amounts to 130 times that amount. Which is a lot. But holy cow 7 bucks well spent. This game is extremely good looking. It is absolutely fantastic. The building is so simple and easy to understand, but the physics is realistic enough to frustrate you and force you to build realistic machines. Don't get me even started on the aesthetics. Dang this game is beautiful. Sometimes I just look at it. Its just nice to look at. Anyway buy this game if you like fun. And you like fun that looks beautiful. This is bascially why indie games are so much better than mainstream stuff.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game really wasn't what I was expecting it to be, and that's partially my fault, but here's what I've got to say:

Pros:
-Allows your creativity to flourish
-Runs really well;  no bugs or glitches so far for me at least
-Cartoon like graphics adds a very fun atmosphere to the game

Cons:
-Very complicated building mechanics
-More often than not, your creations will fail

I'd recommend this game to the people who want a fun challenge for their creativity, but if you're expecting this to be a simple building game like Minecraft or something, then do not buy this game! It can get very frustrating, just like for me. I tried playing it casually, thinking that it was going to be a simple, yet challenging game. Needless to say, out of probably a hundred different vehicles; twenty of them didn't completely fall apart as the game started. Maybe even less actually went on to beat the level.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's one of those has a lot of potential" games.

The graphics are very nice and the physics more or less work fine. Building siege weapons is easy enough even for someone not bless with engineering skills. Though if you think that you can build something that turns and moves quickly and gently - think again. Its more or less "cow on a roller-blades" situation with everything you are going to build.

Flying... doesn't really work. I've tried different ways to build flying mechanisms and all of them cannot be controlled for more than 3 seconds before falling down and breaking into pieces.

At the moment there's nothing really to do here. First island can be finished in under 30 minutes
date: a lot of the sounds are missing
hoursPlayed: very few parts and enemies as well. The sandbox is fun for exactly 10 minutes before you realize that you pretty much tried everything you could to build something amazing and failed miserably.\n\nSo... yeah - it has potential but right now its barren. Though i suppose that the small price is its redeeming quality. You can buy it if you are prepared to wait for whatever amount of time it takes the developers to finish it."
voteText: February 5, 2015

reviewText:
Early Access Review

When I was a small child, I would always draw designs for cars and stuff. Bikes sometimes. Vehicles that moved, and I would come up with all these little mechanisms for them that surely wouldn't work.

And now Besiege has come along and I'm doing it all over again.

The thing that makes this such a great Early Access game is the content and the price. It's currently in active development, not even close to complete, and the content that I have right now is fully worth the $7 price tag to me. The experimentation is simply so joyous. In the few hours I've played so far, I never take the time to fully think my ideas through. I throw them out there, see what works, see what doesn't, and keep adapting them until I have exactly what I want. It's great fun to play with friends around too, as group idea sessions are the best kind of idea sessions.

Any negatives? Obviously early access and unfinished, but again, worthy content already, My only qualm is the guilt I feel when I accidentally murder an innocent sheep, but I'm quickly becoming numb.

Definitely recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have the Siege board game in my closet right now. It has been gathering dust since I left my parents' carpeted house over a decade ago...so happy to see this game brought to life in a way.

You can complete the missions in any way you can figure it out; rams, projectiles, flames, mechanisms, etc. The free-form building reminds me of KSP a bit.

Exactly as advertised in the video - and better than expected. Here is some gameplay...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3W2sIFKlny0

Make unique complex siege machines and put them to task in a simplistic yet beautiful world - for destruction and a couple other tasks. How can a game with exploding sheep be this elegant?

Very impressed!

I haven't had this much fun with a game in a long while. It's like lego on steriods. It is such a simple game but allows you to be so creative in making some really unique, interesting, complex, hilarious, and disasterous machines. reviewText:
Early Access Review

So pretty much you start out on the first stage, you build a siege engine to knock down the small cottage and you go to the next level which will be a building that's harder to knock down. You start out with the siege engine you made during the last level and if it doesn't work, you can either alter it or start fresh. Really great game. Very unique and gorgeous graphics. My only real critique of this game is that camera controls are a little confusing starting out and it's not initially clear how all of the driving/flying parts work.

I'd give this game a strong 8.5/10. 10/10 if they include a tutorial. Very well done.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy first creation in this game was a small vehicle covered in cannons and flamethrowers.  It worked fine, but by the time I got to the fourth level, I needed some protection and a way to dispatch the wall in front of me.  So, I countered that wall with a wall of my own, covered in armor plates and cannons.  When I fired it, it blasted the opposing wall apart and was sent flying backwards from the recoil and rolled (surprisingly harmlessly) over my vehicle, which I then drove around the flaming wreckage of the wall to destroy the rest of everything.  When I got to the iron stealing level, I dropped the vehicle entirely and went with a cannon turret which knocked the ore balls into the target zone from afar.  Since then, I've mostly been trying to find ways to complete every objective with pretty much cannons only.  What I'm saying is, buy this game and use cannons for everything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Besiege is a game where you have to design a siege engine to complete a task such as carrying a material from point A to B, destroying/killing a certain amount of structures/NPCs, or passing checkpoints.
It has some optimization flaws, but that is expected. This is a good game for making you think outside the box for a solution and having a laugh when it all goes horribly wrong. For the price it is worth it. The only limits are the tools and your imagination.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For years, I struggled with hard drug abuse. I was hooked on various drugs until they could no longer please me, so I would move to more intense, more addictive drugs. I ended up with a crippling heroin addiction. Luckily, my wife and family were there to support me and try to get me back on track.  They put me through therapy, but I just couldn't put down the needle. My therapist suggested I find a hobby that could keep my mind off of the drugs, but every hobby I tried just couldn't supersede the addiction heroin. That is, until I found this game. Since beginning to play this game, heroin has never crossed my mind. The addiction I feel for this game has completely obliterated the addiction level I had for heroin. I never thought it was possible, but since purchasing this game, my life has gotten far worse.  My addiction to this game took everything from me. My wife, my house, my kids. Everything. So if you're looking at this game and deciding whether or not to purchase it, consider your life as it is now.  Because once you purchase this game, you can't go back. It will change you, consume you, ruin you.

TL;DR: Buy it, it's tight

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAn awesome game, it is early access but as long as they keep pushing content it will be awesome. Even if they didn't I would be happy knowing I spent $7 on it. There are some serious lag problems when your machine gets very complicated, but I found you just have to adjust your design to work around it. I'd LOVE for them to add Joystick support and maybe even an advanced mode where you can change even more properties (hinge friction, weight of blocks, etc.) All in all it is a great game and part of that is its simplicity.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNice physics, good controls. If they finish the game using design which is this good, it's going to be great. Even with a relatively limited amount of building blocks, you can build really nice machines, since the blocks are well chosen. They will probably add more, but even like this, it is a good compromise between having a compact set of blocks (so that they are easy to remember and find) and a lot of building options. Also, since you can define which keys control each block, you can even do things like differential tank-like steering, where you control wheels on each side separately, allowing you to turn on the spot.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlready very fun, but has potential for so much more. Gorgeous graphics and artstyle. Nice looking minimalistic interface (maybe a little too minimalistic). Right now, the game sorely lacks the ability to move segments of the machine independently from each other. If you wanna make a longer arm for your catapult, you have to delete the whole thing and build it again instead of just making it longer. But that will come, I'm sure. I just hope the development will be rapid and will lead to a finished product, which is far too uncommon for early access games, unfortunately.

Now that I have had a chance to really test this game out, I still say that this game is amazing. Running it on a not terrible but not gaming worthy laptop with a i7 and 4400 integrated graphics, I have to really try to make the game lag. I love the openness of the game too. I can build a very serious catapult or trebuchet and spend and hour fine tunning it, or I can build a giant, 20x20 mat of bombs just for the heck of it. I've done both. A game that, for a very low price, allows you to do whatever you want (as long as you have enough braces!) and watch it work beautifully or fail fantastically and have fun the entire time is a game that should be up there with the greates. I just hope, niet, pray that the developers keep it simple and open as it currently is and that they do not give in to greed and pressure like other indie games. Looking at you, Starbound.

A simply elegant physics based sandbox and puzzler. Building these strange medieval siege weapon inspired machines with the nice selection of parts is a rather fun diversion. First release to Early Access nearly flawless (could do with volume sliders and more tutorials), and hopefully things proceed well from here forward.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Happy to see it on Steam where it's easily accesible for everyone to buy.

The game itself is amazing, especially if you like games with realistic-ish physics. You can build your own war machines in a medieval landscape. The levels that are out now include building a machine to slay soldiers, destroying castles and even slaughter sheep.

+ Your imagination is the limit. Flying machines, tanks, and even simple catapults, it's all there.
+ The challenges are quite nice. They try and have you create different contraptions for each level, so the building will not get boring quickly.
+ It's still in development, but the game is almost bugfree. I am yet to encounter one myself, and I find that quite the accomplishment for it being alpha.

- If they don't come up with many different types of levels and challenges the game might get repetitive. This is not yet the case, but you can never be sure.
- The tooltips ingame don't help you make use of every single tool. The items themselves have good tooltips, but some of the universal tools don't get enough explanation during the game. For a few of the tools I had to watch youtube videos.

Once again, I'm very excited to see this game on Steam. Having followed this game for quite a while now I'm happy to see the popularity. Curious what the developers will add in the future!

So pretty much you start out on the first stage, you build a siege engine to knock down the small cottage and you go to the next level which will be a building that's harder to knock down. You start out with the siege engine you made during the last level and if it doesn't work, you can either alter it or start fresh. Really great game. Very unique and gorgeous graphics. My only real critique of this game is that camera controls are a little confusing starting out and it's not initially clear how all of the driving/flying parts work.

I'd give this game a strong 8.5/10. 10/10 if they include a tutorial. Very well done.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nMy first creation in this game was a small vehicle covered in cannons and flamethrowers.  It worked fine, but by the time I got to the fourth level, I needed some protection and a way to dispatch the wall in front of me.  So, I countered that wall with a wall of my own, covered in armor plates and cannons.  When I fired it, it blasted the opposing wall apart and was sent flying backwards from the recoil and rolled (surprisingly harmlessly) over my vehicle, which I then drove around the flaming wreckage of the wall to destroy the rest of everything.  When I got to the iron stealing level, I dropped the vehicle entirely and went with a cannon turret which knocked the ore balls into the target zone from afar.  Since then, I've mostly been trying to find ways to complete every objective with pretty much cannons only.  What I'm saying is, buy this game and use cannons for everything.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's like somebody saw how my friends and I played with legos as kids and turned it into a game.

While the early access version (as of v 0.4) is light on scenarios/puzzles, the siege-engine building is fully functional and remarkably fun.  It is easy to construct a basic working siege engine in a few minutes though more time and experimentation is rewarded as the simulation and construction tools allow you to create everything from basic catapults to walking/flying/transforming death machines.

The only thing that could be said to be missing at this point is a suite of puzzles/challenges commensurate to the tools you are given.  The current puzzle set serves as a good basic tutorial but does not offer much challenge on its own.   Once beaten, the available levels and the sandbox mode mostly serve as testing grounds in which to play around with building even more insane creations.  There are many more levels in development, but if sandbox construction doesn't sound like your thing it might make sense to hold off until the rest of the levels are completed.

Even at this early stage it is worth the price of admission; if you do not tend to buy early access titles then keep an eye on this one as it is sure to be even more impressive at launch.    While the devs are still adding more features at this point and have yet to add most of the pre-built challenge levels, there's still enough here to provide several hours of great entertainment already - if you enjoy making giant dancing robots who tear themselves to pieces as they crush medieval villages under foot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In terms of graphics, art style and UI - this is the most beautiful game I've ever played. The DoF is used very well, as is the vignette and everything else to give it a very 'crisp' and 'smooth' feel.

The gameplay itself is fairly simple, but with tons of possibilities. Each level can be solved in a multitude of ways, and that's just assuming you actually want to solve it and not make a trebuchet that fires smaller catapults with flamethrowers on them.

The only criticism I have is that it has very few levels so far, but it's quite obvious that the developer plans to add a lot more, so take that with a grain of salt. I'm not sure if it's planned, but a level creator would be very advantageous in this game, because even with the dev releasing more levels there'll still be a demand for more, and given how most levels are constructed I can see a simple level editor being quite easy to use.

10/10 would fire a flamethrower catapult out of a trebuchet again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

What a game.... for the extremely low cost of £4.99, you'll get some laughs.
Granted its in alpha so wont be perfect but here's my thoughts:

Pros:
Graphics
Lagless, seamless experience
Excellent physics
The ability to build whatever you can imagine(ish)

Cons:
A simply tutorial would be nice - movement/pivots etc, I actually dont know the purpose of 2 objects because I can't phathom what to do with said items, but maybe im dense.
The grey/fog surround, I understand why its in place as opposed to an environment theme, but gets tired quickly

Recommendations for future development:

Imagine this crazily hilarious game as Robot Wars style, go head to head with others in an arena which has its trap doors, its own circular saws, fire pits, first build to perish loses... maybe even some 'House Robots' - would be awesome to see what builds the developers come up with

User created levels, and a user created levels online base so you can play on other peoples 'maps' , some = carnage, some = challenging, some = epic!
There's my 2p

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nNice physics, good controls. If they finish the game using design which is this good, it's going to be great. Even with a relatively limited amount of building blocks, you can build really nice machines, since the blocks are well chosen. They will probably add more, but even like this, it is a good compromise between having a compact set of blocks (so that they are easy to remember and find) and a lot of building options. Also, since you can define which keys control each block, you can even do things like differential tank-like steering, where you control wheels on each side separately, allowing you to turn on the spot.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a fantastic Indie Game, that really unleashes your creativity, as well as being really fun to play. In the game you are able to make whatever your heart desires, all with a physics style that is sure to put a smile on your face. You can include weapons, armour and flying components to make basic or more advanced killing machines, either to complete missions, or just for fun in sandbox mode. Some of the more advanced machines are much more difficult to build, but fun is guaranteed along the way.
The user Interface is perfectly designed, and very simple to use, with even the more advanced tools being as simple to use as the game is to play. The graphics look fantastic, and the game runs brilliantly, and really seeing sheep explode in a firey blood bath seems a great addition to the game.
I would rate the game 10/10 for fun, 9/10 for the creativity made possible, 10/10 for the graphical style, and 9/10 just for the physics alone.
Overall rating: 9/10, well worth checking out, and I am really looking forward to updates in the future.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game has far exceeded my expectations and at this price I cannot recommend it highly enough.

The joy of seeing your seige engine destoy a group of soldiers (or sheep) and a village doesn't get old. The current accessible continent is a good tutorial with some simple objectives using the items avaliable. On each level you can use all the blocks for building a seige engine with various weapons for the situation.

I really like the look of this game, the plain white back ground with the scenery surrounding the objective colourful and interesting to look at. The textures and graphics are very good and i have no noticed any bugs or missing textures for objects. The camera controls are good but would like to be able to move the pan controls to the number pad!

The basic physics and mechanics work well and are totally usuable now to build some mad devices of destruction. I found the framerate dropping when using large structures (over 200 blocks I believe) but most of the time it barely faultered. I hope to see more of the levels using what can be seen in Sandbox mode to add more challenge.

I have to say for an early access this is very promising and will be very interested in what happens with each update and what will happen when the modding community gets going. I can see alot of potential and would like to see this game do well.

I wonder if it could be ported to Andorid and iOS in the future...

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's basically all the mechanical features that I would have loved to have in minecraft. It plays solidly, and is very polished (for an alpha). I have noticed no game breaking bugs thus far, and the only serious inconvenience comes in the form of chugging with more complex structures. The camera controls could also use some work (there is no veritcal movement, just horizontal). So with only two minor problems I've noticed, plus a good deal of polish, I'd say that it's worth the low price as is. It reminds me a lot of Banjo Kazooie: Nuts and Bolts.

There's still a lot of potential, and I hope they fully explore it. I have the feeling that they'll change the way supports work, but right now they're really convenient, and I hope they don't. The game is a sandbox, so your creativity is only limited by what tools they put in place. I'm hoping they'll give us magical blocks or weapons, such as lodestones, or staffs of lightning that you can strap to your machine. We've got the basics, and they're good. The game is solid. Here's hoping they fully explore the possibilities and don't limit themselves.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI normally boicot Early Access games after the Godus fiasco, but this one deserves your attention right from the start. The game is minimalistic building siege engines simulator, with very small amount of missions for now.  The game has a TON of potential though, and replayability for the few missions is only kept low by your imagination and interest to build and try out your own contraptions. The things I've made so far include: Helicopter, Catapult, (still working on a Trebuchet since it is real hard to make on this), Tank. I've also seen people make a transformer in this so as you can see there's much to try out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For years, I struggled with hard drug abuse. I was hooked on various drugs until they could no longer please me, so I would move to more intense, more addictive drugs. I ended up with a crippling heroin addiction. Luckily, my wife and family were there to support me and try to get me back on track.  They put me through therapy, but I just couldn't put down the needle. My therapist suggested I find a hobby that could keep my mind off of the drugs, but every hobby I tried just couldn't supersede the addiction heroin. That is, until I found this game. Since beginning to play this game, heroin has never crossed my mind. The addiction I feel for this game has completely obliterated the addiction level I had for heroin. I never thought it was possible, but since purchasing this game, my life has gotten far worse.  My addiction to this game took everything from me. My wife, my house, my kids. Everything. So if you're looking at this game and deciding whether or not to purchase it, consider your life as it is now.  Because once you purchase this game, you can't go back. It will change you, consume you, ruin you.

TL;DR: Buy it, it's tight

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Steam Review -  Beat a castle by building a pyramid of explosvies and ramming it through soldiers to hit the walls. 10/10

Serious review:
This game is excellent, and even at it's current level, I would be quite happy to pay £2-3 for it.

However, the game menu (a beautiful spinning globe) shows several levels, portrayed as continents, that are purportedly 'under construction' along with a sandbox mode. When (hopefully) these come out, the game will quite probably take many hours to complete. My current playtime of 3.2 hours was enough to complete the current levels, while mucking about with various ways to kill sheep, and so is probably 2 hours play for someone new, with no ideas borrowed from videos. For only £4.99, and the hope of another 3-5 campaigns of the same length, this gives better £ to hour ratio than I expected, and certainly beats some of the more expensive games availble.
I highly recommend this, however, before you build a metal plated explosive firing tank, be aware, I did this, and my FPS promtly dropped to 5. Whether this is unavoidable or not I don't know, it may have been the object I made, but I hope the developers add either better optimisation for more 'parts' of vehicles, or add larger blocks, such as a 5x2 metal plate, so you can armour things without playing a slideshow.
However, other than that small qualm, this game is absolutely excellent, and will easily provide hours of entertaining play.
